3. Diyaluma Falls The Photograph show Diyaluma Falls, the highest waterfall in Ceylon and the sixth highest in the world. Diyaluma covers a fall of 570 ft and is one of the most picturesque sights in the hill country of Ceylon.

Verso: 3. Diyaluma Falls The Photograph show Diyaluma Falls, the highest waterfall in Ceylon and the sixth highest in the world. Diyaluma covers a fall of 570 ft and is one of the most picturesque sights in the hill country of Ceylon.

4. The Vatadage The photograph shows the ruins of Vatadage, a circular shrine in Ceylon built in 1196 A.D. Four Buddha figures face the four entrances. The shrine is situated in Polonnaruwa, one of the ancient capitals of Ceylon.

Verso: 4. The Vatadage The photograph shows the ruins of Vatadage, a circular shrine in Ceylon built in 1196 A.D. Four Buddha figures face the four entrances. The shrine is situated in Polonnaruwa, one of the ancient capitals of Ceylon.

1. Sigiriya Rock The photograph show the famous Sigiriya Rock in Ceylon. The massive granite rock, which rises to a height of 600 ft., was converted into a fortress by a King named Kasyapa in the 5th century A.D. The King built a palace, baths, pavilions and a storage tank on the for acres of ground at the summit of the rock. A feature of the Sigiriya Rock is its frescoes which are considered masterpieces of art. The frescoes portray beautiful damsels presumably from King Kasyapa's Court.

Verso: 1. Sigiriya Rock The photograph show the famous Sigiriya Rock in Ceylon. The massive granite rock, which rises to a height of 600 ft., was converted into a fortress by a King named Kasyapa in the 5th century A.D. The King built a palace, baths, pavilions and a storage tank on the for acres of ground at the summit of the rock. A feature of the Sigiriya Rock is its frescoes which are considered masterpieces of art. The frescoes portray beautiful damsels presumably from King Kasyapa's Court.
14. Ceylon Leopard Wild Life in the Ceylon National Parks at Wilpattu and Yala are popular tourist attractions. The picture shows a leopard waiting for its prey in one of the National Parks.
Verso: 14. Ceylon Leopard Wild Life in the Ceylon National Parks at Wilpattu and Yala are popular tourist attractions. The picture shows a leopard waiting for its prey in one of the National Parks.

2. The Ruanvelisaya The photograph show the Ruanvelisaya, a dagoba in Ceylon built in the year 123 B.C. The Ruanvelisaya, is held in special veneration by the Buddhists of Ceylon. Its height is 300 ft. with an equivalent diameter at its base. It was built by Dutugemunu, one of the greatest Kings of ancient Ceylon.

Subject files: World War II (radio commentators tour of the war fronts)

A NINTH AIR FORCE BOMBER BASE, France---Lowell Thomas, noted war correspondent and radio commentator discusses questions of tactical air power with Major Hwang T's-Piao and Major Chen Yu-Feng (right) at a Ninth Air Force bomber base.; The correspondents, of which Mr. Thomas was a member, visited the base of the 410th Light Bombardment Group, in France, to see how the tactical air force operates. The two Chinese airmen are attached to the Ninth Air Force as observers for the Chinese Air Force

Note: [press release] A NINTH AIR FORCE BOMBER BASE, France---Lowell Thomas, noted war correspondent and radio commentator discusses questions of tactical air power with Major Hwang T's-Piao and Major Chen Yu-Feng (right) at a Ninth Air Force bomber base.; The correspondents, of which Mr. Thomas was a member, visited the base of the 410th Light Bombardment Group, in France, to see how the tactical air force operates. The two Chinese airmen are attached to the Ninth Air Force as observers for the Chinese Air Force

SCORE CARD - Captain Donald N. Aldrich of the Marine Corps, Chicago's leading aerial ace, smiles from his fighter plane in the South Pacific. The 20 Japanese flags painted on the plane are eloquent testimony that 20 Rising Sun aircraft will rise no more. Captain Aldrich downed that many Japanese planes and won the Distinguished Flying Cross doing so. He is one of five Marine Corps aces who have shot down as many as 20 planes

Flying Officer Robert Joseph Campbell, D.F.C., of Pawling, N.Y., who was recently awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross while serving with the Royal Canadian Air Force in Britain as an air gunner. Flying Officer Campbell, who was born in Scotland, was educated at Pawling High School and at Milford School, Milford, Connecticut. His citation reads "Flying Officer Campbell has distinguished himself by his courageous behavior, efficiency and enthusiasm for operations, which has made a notable contribution to the successes achieved by his squadron."

Verso: THE STORY OF JOHNNIE HUTCHINS Son of a Texas sharecropper, Seaman First Class Johnnie David Hutchins, USNR, died a hero's death off Lae, New Guinea, on September 4, 1943--clinging to the wheel of LST (Landing Ship Tank) 473 after receiving a mortal wound, and using his last strength to turn the ship out of the path of a Japanese torpedo during the Allied invasion of New Guinea. He has been awarded the Medal of Honor for his bravery...

TOP-FLIGHT TRIO -Ranking members of the Fighting Corsairs Marine squadron, who between them have accounted for 60 Japanese planes, are shown here. At the left is First Lieutenant Robert M. Hanson of Newtonville, Mass., who was declared missing in action after downing his 25th enemy plane, one short of the American record. In the center is Captain Harold L. Spears of Ironton, O. [Ohio], who has downed 15 planes. At the right is Captain Donald N. Aldrich of Chicago, with 20 planes to his credit. The Fighting Corsairs set five all-time Marine aviation records during their tours of duty in the South Pacific. Lieutenant Hanson and Captain Aldrich were the highest scoring pair in the squadron

TOKYO RAIDERS REUNION ON FIRST ANNIVERSARY; AFRICA - Major General Jimmy Doolittle (third from left, front row) who led the air raid on Japan on April 18, 1942, and some of the men who flew with him, are drinking a champagne toast from coffee cups during a reunion in North Africa on the first anniversary of the flight. The party was held in an Arab's barn which had been turned into an Officer's Club. Left to right, front row, Major William Bower, Ravenna, [California?]; Major Travis Hoover, Arlington, California; Doolittle; Lieutenant Colonel Harvey Hinman, San Francisco; Captain Heston C. Daniel, Plaquemine, Louisiana. Back row, left to right - Captain Howard A. Sessler of Arlington, Massachusetts; Captain William R. Pound, Jr., Kent Homes, Virginia; Major Rodney R. Wilder of Taylor, Texas; Captain James M. Parker, Livingston, Texas; Major Charles R. Greening, Tacoma, Washington; Major Joseph Klein, Paradise, Texas; Captain Griffith P. William, San Diego, California; and Captain Thomas C. Griffin of Chicago (E-7-15-43)

The sun shows a new face when viewed from a Naval Research Laboratory rocket 123 miles high. This unusual photo--a "first"--presents the sun as recorded in detail in the extreme ultraviolet region of the spectrum. This is one in a series of rocket astronomy experiments being conducted by the Naval Research Laboratory under the auspices of the International Geophysical Year. (Photo taken on 13 March 1959). (Note: the large bright areas at the edge of the disc shoudl be on the viewer's right).
